docs.title: Hello World!
docs.text:
Hi, I'm Manuarsan and this is the first entry of this blog. If this is the first time we meet, hi! You can call me just Manu.

So, what is this site about and why I'm I building it? And how am I developing this blog? All those answers will hopefully get answered either in this first entry or in later ones.

So let's just get started.

docs.title: What is this site about?
docs.text:
First of all

This site is meant to be some kind of journal for me to just help organize my mind.

I am a technical writer. I've actually been a tech writer for many years if not my entire career, where I've applied technical communication in way or another.

I am 37 years old. I live in Barcelona, Spain. I will talk more about my experience later, but even though I don't fully know yet what this site will be about, one thing is for sure: it will include content about writing, not just technical writing but also creative and even copywriting, and about learning experience design. It will also have my personal reflections about the power of words in general. I may also add some gaming or gamification topics. Becuase one of the things I'm most passionate about is learning by playing.

docs.title: Why am I creating this site?
docs.text:
Because I'm purpose-driven. And my purpose has been changing or, put it in better words, evolving.

The word evolving is key because it reflects one of the more important things I've been thinking about lately: something I just call the career compound interest. I'm sure there's a better way to call it but I will try to explain it now:

What do I mean by career compount interest?

Ok, so I've actually used chatGPT to search for that. I don't know where I read or heard that concept before, but I'm just rewriting the definition:

Career compound interest means that small efforts you make early in your career grow into much bigger rewards later - just like money earning interest in a bank.

That may be confusing for some, but lifechanging for others. It's being lifechanging for me at least.

Actually, thinking about career compound interest makes fe feel freer. Let me explain.

Overall, I just want to live well enough to be able to provide my family with a life better than the one that I'm having now so we can enjoy the better future together.

But there are some uncertain events that are impacting my confidence. I even stopped watching the news because it just filled my mind with more chaos than the mess I already had. For example, the layoffs that are happening in the software industry nowadays are truly shocking.

Thousands of employees have been laid off in less than one year. I'm still there, but that makes me think about how to bring myself together and regain control of my mental - and corporal too - wellbeing.

So I think: Is my career still relevant in the present and future? I guess it is, but how can I feel even more confident about it?

Should I evaluate other career options that may reinforce the impact of my role even more than now?

What am I supposed to do? Do I need a plan B? Or is it better to just keep the focus on the current plan A as the only plan if we can even call it that way because, really, what's the plan?

I've worked in many different things since I was 16 years old. It is not easy to think of myself as a specialist - tho I think I am in one way or another due to the career decisions I've made in the recent years.

And the main reason why I'm building this site is to clarify what my professional specialization is, if any, and keep growing my career compound interest.

This feels more important than ever for me at this stage of my life.

I got married in December (so not even a couple of months ago yet). I traveled to Japan and it was great. I've been with my wife for 15 years now - such a milestone. And the family could grow in the near future. So yeah, job and income stability is critical.

And I'm one of the lucky ones because throughout my career I've build many projects and learned a lot of skills - now the question is, how do those skills complement each other towards the same goal? And what is that goal?

I think I have some good answers too all those questions. But I just one to keep thinking and writing them down. And writing them well.

Because, as the American writer Ambrose Bierce said:

Good writing is clear thinking made visible.

I'll keep writing, but for now I need to pause. Time for lunch.

But I'm happy, I've just written this page in Markdown and -

Wait, Markdown, really? - you might be wondering. The answer is: yes. But I'll talk more about that in maybe the 3rd blog post?

For the 2nd one, I'll share what my career so far looks like. Brace yourself.

(It's funny because I'm writig this to myself basically but I may publish this on a website - I used to be, and still sometimes act as a, web developer).

So if I've published this and you've read this, nice! Thank you and until next time :)

docs.title: Career Compounding Interest Reflection
docs.text:
This week I've been reflecting on several things about what my future should look like and what are the things I should focus on based on my past experiences.

In my first post, I mentioned how I'm passionate about learning by playing. That thing has influenced my career since the beginning one way or another. Let me show you what I mean.

docs.title: The beginning
docs.text:
I started working when I was 16 at a fast food restaurant in Barcelona. I was the youngest employee by a significant difference. I was living in a different city and had to take the first train available in the morning to get to work on time.

I actually left Bachillerato - which were optional studies before University - just to work because we needed income in the house. And it was a pain, especially for my mother since she wanted me to keep studying.

I remember the person who was going to be my boss at the restaurant telling my mother: "He will study here at the job - there are many things to learn about the food, the ingredients, and operations." And my mother was kind of happy to hear that.

I did learn a lot. Really. Not just about the food, cleaning, how to make cute coffees when dropping the milk to draw hearts, for example. I also learned a lot about people. You know, you end up greeting and serving a huge amount of people throughout a day, week, and years. And also about how to get along with your teammates. To know your limits by crossing them.

I eventually saw some areas for improvement. For example, how to identify and use different cleaning cloths for different areas. We had three: the blue cloth was for the tables where clients sat in the dining area, the pink one was for the toilet, and the white one was for the kitchen. So basic, yet not so easy to know if no documentation or onboarding is done for that. So I created my first technical communication there. It was a drawing that we hung on the wall in the kitchen near the cleaning supplies.

First career compound interest deposit

Looking back, that simple drawing was my first step into technical communication. I didn't know it back then, but I was solving real problems through clear communication.

Almost 2 years later, I became a staff manager. I got promoted. So you can bet I was scared of having to tell people who could be my grandparents what to do. And not just that - other young people and even a few younger than me who had just started for summer jobs. But I think I was still the youngest? I don't remember that well.

I just know I learned interesting stuff about the power of words. For example, if I told someone "do it", it wasn't that good. But if I told them "do X while we do Y so that we'll be able to accomplish Z mission", then it was great. And if I said a word with a negative connotation, others would copy and there would be a more toxic environment. But if I kept optimistic, the environment would just feel awesome.

I rejoined classes while working, so I studied in the morning and worked in the evenings. I eventually left the job and did other fast food work while at university - and even worked at a supermarket too for a while.

docs.title: After university: the creator phase
docs.text:
As soon as I finished university - after having studied in California for the last year as an exchange student and many adventures - I started teaching English to Spanish and Catalan speakers. I taught in different places: schools, academies, 1-to-1 sessions in students' houses, and in cafés around different cities.

I also self-learned how to build websites and create online courses.

Later, I wrote books. I created other courses about writing besides English. I taught at places like Udemy, for example, where I reached over 30k students. And I also freelanced as a writing consultant - copywriting, technical writing, creative writing - and for front-end web development.

I became a front-end web developer by self-learning and was employed at a startup that went from around 70 people when I joined to 200 when I left after two years. I learned a lot there. I started in a technical support position and then became a technical writer, creating documentation and onboarding programs for new employees.

I left the company to continue learning and building projects on my own. I built over 10 websites about different topics to learn SEO. I created many different social media accounts about each of those topics: how to become fit at home, how to write a novel, home decoration, and English as a second language.

The goal was to write about things I was interested in and see if they ranked on Google when people searched for related terms. So I learned to develop blogging and educational websites. This included technical writing to explain how a stationary bike worked, for example, but also summarizing scientific research papers about how to build muscle into plain language via text and video.

I also had clients as a freelance writing consultant about many different topics.

docs.title: Where I am now
docs.text:
Eventually I was hired at the company where I currently work as a technical writer, but I do a lot of learning experience design too. I can apply creative things like demo situations for people to learn about data-related topics through some sort of interactive novel. I use front-end web dev skills and storytelling to make the learning process not just practical but also engaging.

I play video games too - maybe 1 hour daily right after dinner. Weekends maybe 2 hours daily when I can.

So what does this all mean?

Looking at this journey, I think focusing on creating learning by playing experiences is a good evolution for my career compound interest nowadays.

docs.title: Should I switch careers?
docs.text:
So I don't think I should switch careers at all. I think technical communication has a lot of potential ahead nowadays because it is not just about turning complex information into easy-to-digest pieces of content. It is also about verifying something works, which is crucial in the age of AI.

And also, I think the human experience is going to feel premium. Let's say AI creates something and you say "ok." But if there's a human telling you the same thing, you'll probably feel more inclined to trust the human - provided the information is properly sourced, updated, and verified.

Writing is still important. It makes us think. I've seen articles about people becoming less sharp since AI came into play. I think AI is a good partner to help your writing, not replace it. It can help bridge the development phase and the production phase - turning your thoughts into something easy for others to understand.

If you don't just let it replace your thoughts, but help it channel them, I can see how it can propel you to an increased career compound interest. Not just as a tech writer, but also in any other position where thinking and strategy are at the core of the role.

docs.title: What's next?
docs.text:
Having said that, I'm not thinking about Plan B. But one of my goals for this year that I just defined this week is to learn more about investments to improve personal finance and simplify my life.

How and what? You may learn that in the third episode of this journal.

Until next time.

docs.title: Why Learning About Investments Can Make Tech Comm Matter More
docs.text:
I've been learning the basics of how businesses are measured—things like EBIT, EBITDA, and why investors and executives care about them. Not to become a finance person, but to understand the language of the room where decisions get made. And it turns out: that language has a lot to do with what we do in tech comm and learning design.

So here's the idea: if we can explain what those numbers mean using analogies from our own field, we understand them better. And if we can show how great onboarding and learning experiences improve those numbers, we can make the case for tech comm having a real, measurable impact on the business.

docs.title: My investment journey (so far)
docs.text:
I've been investing for a while now, mainly in index funds and money market funds, and also in some individual company stocks. I love the power of compound interest—not just in career growth, but in actual financial investments too.

But here's the thing: the challenging part isn't the act of investing itself, or even automating it. It's making the decision and commitment to keep going with it. Not trying different things all the time, but learning different things about the same thing.

That's what makes career compound interest work, in my opinion. You don't jump from topic to topic. You go deeper—learning about something from different angles, building expertise layer by layer. You ensure that the low points don't make you abandon ship, and you let the good periods compound on top of the foundation you've built.

This applies to everything—career, relationships, investments. Commitments work through compound interest too. Getting married, for example, creates compound interest in one way or another. It makes you free knowing your priority and what to focus on.

Now I'm learning about investments more deeply so I can select specific stocks instead of just broad-market funds. I want to know where I'm investing and why, hoping for higher returns. And to do that well, I need to understand what makes a business valuable to investors.

docs.title: What the heck is EBIT (or EBITDA)? And why net benefit matters more
docs.text:
EBIT = Earnings Before Interest and Taxes. EBITDA = Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization.

These measure how much money the core business is making from operations—before accounting for financing costs (interest), taxes, asset depreciation, and amortization.

Tech comm analogy

Think of EBITDA like measuring documentation "engagement" without considering the full cost. You might say "50,000 users viewed our docs this month!" But if it required 8 full-time writers, 2 designers, a dedicated documentation manager, expensive tools, ongoing training, and constant maintenance to achieve that, was it actually valuable? EBITDA is similar—it shows operational performance but doesn't show the complete picture of what it costs to run.

docs.title: Why net benefit (profit) matters more than EBIT or EBITDA
docs.text:
Here's the problem: EBIT and EBITDA can make a struggling business look healthy because they exclude real costs.

Depreciation isn't just accounting—it represents equipment that actually needs replacing. Interest payments are real money leaving the bank. Taxes must be paid. Ignoring these makes the numbers look better than reality.

What actually matters: Net benefit (or net profit)

In plain English: Did you make more money than you spent? That's net benefit. That's profit.

Think of it like your personal budget: - You earn $5,000/month (revenue) - You spend $3,000 on rent, food, bills, everything (expenses) - You have $2,000 left over (net benefit/profit)

EBITDA would be like saying "I earned $5,000 and only spent $1,500 on food and utilities!" while conveniently ignoring your $1,500 rent payment. Sure, your "food and utilities performance" looks great, but you're still only saving $2,000.

The fundamental truth is simpler: Revenue must grow faster than expenses over time.

If a company reports 30% revenue growth but expenses also grew 30%, nothing really improved—they just got bigger. But if revenue grows 30% while expenses only grow 20%, now you're seeing real value creation. The gap between revenue and expenses is widening. That's actual profit growth.

Tech comm version

Good internal documentation should reduce total costs (employee onboarding time, developer questions, repeated explanations, mistakes) MORE than it costs to create and maintain. If your internal docs team costs $400k/year but cuts onboarding time by 3 weeks per employee (saving $800k annually across 100 new hires), reduces developer support questions (freeing up $600k in senior engineer time), and prevents costly mistakes through clear runbooks, that's massive net benefit. That's real value.

docs.title: But what investors really care about: ROIC
docs.text:
Now here's where it gets interesting. Profit is good, but what matters even more is Return on Invested Capital (ROIC).

ROIC answers the question: "For every dollar you invest in the business, how much profit do you generate?"

docs.title: The ROIC formula (simplified)
docs.text:
ROIC = Net Profit / Invested Capital

In plain English: - Net Profit: What you make after all expenses - Invested Capital: The money you had to put in to run the business (equipment, people, inventory, etc.) - ROIC: How efficiently you turn that investment into profit

docs.title: Personal finance analogy
docs.text:
Imagine two investment options:

Option A: - You invest $100,000 - You make $10,000 profit per year - ROIC = 10%

Option B: - You invest $20,000 - You make $10,000 profit per year - ROIC = 50%

Both make the same $10,000 profit, but Option B is WAY better because it requires less capital to generate the same return. You could take that extra $80,000 and invest it elsewhere!

docs.title: Why ROIC matters more than profit
docs.text:
A company making $1 million profit sounds great. But: - If it required $100 million invested to make that $1M (ROIC = 1%), that's terrible - If it only required $2 million invested to make that $1M (ROIC = 50%), that's excellent

High ROIC means the business is capital-efficient. It doesn't need to keep pouring money in to grow. It generates strong returns on what's already invested.

This is the holy grail for investors—and it connects directly to operating leverage and compound interest.

docs.title: The tech comm ROIC analogy
docs.text:
Think about internal documentation investment this way:

Low ROIC documentation approach: - Invest $500k/year in a large internal docs team - Create comprehensive documentation for everything, much of it rarely consulted - Save $600k in reduced onboarding time and fewer repeated questions - Net benefit: $100k - "ROIC": 20% return on investment

High ROIC documentation approach: - Invest $300k/year in a focused internal docs team - Create strategic documentation targeting the 20% that solves 80% of problems (Pareto!) - Critical onboarding workflows - Common developer setup issues - Frequently-referenced architecture decisions - Standard operating procedures for complex processes - Save $900k through dramatically faster onboarding, fewer interruptions to senior engineers, and reduced errors - Net benefit: $600k - "ROIC": 200% return on investment

Same goal (enable employees to work efficiently), but the second approach is far more capital-efficient. Less money invested, better results, higher return.

docs.title: How to increase ROIC in tech comm
docs.text:
1. Focus on high-leverage content — The 20% of docs that solve 80% of problems
  2. Build reusable systems — Templates, component libraries, automated processes
  3. Enable self-service at scale — One doc serves thousands without proportional cost increase
  4. Reduce maintenance burden — Evergreen content that doesn't need constant updates
  5. Measure what matters — Track deflection rate, time-to-productivity, not just pages written

This is why understanding business metrics matters. It's not about becoming a finance person—it's about seeing that capital efficiency (ROIC) is what separates good investments from great ones.

And documentation? When done right, it's a high-ROIC investment.

docs.title: What's next: Understanding the balance sheet
docs.text:
ROIC connects profit (from the income statement) with capital (from the balance sheet). To really understand ROIC, you need to understand what "invested capital" means—what the business owns, what it owes, and how that creates value.

That's where the balance sheet comes in. And as I've been learning about balance sheets, I realized: documentation is an asset. Documentation debt is a liability. And the difference between them is equity—real business value.

But that's a topic for the next post.

docs.title: Operating leverage: the compound interest of business
docs.text:
Operating leverage is how a company can amplify its profits when revenue grows, because many of its costs are fixed.

Think of a software company that builds a product once but sells it to thousands of customers. Each new sale has very high profit margins because the main costs—development, infrastructure—don't increase proportionally.

A 10% increase in sales might lead to a 30% increase in profits. That's operating leverage in action.

docs.title: How this connects to compound interest and the Pareto principle
docs.text:
Operating leverage connects beautifully with both compound interest and the Pareto principle:

The Pareto principle

The Pareto principle, also known as the 80/20 rule, states that roughly 80% of consequences come from 20% of causes. In business, this often means 80% of results come from 20% of efforts, or 80% of sales come from 20% of customers.

  • Compound interest connection: Just like investments grow exponentially over time, businesses with high operating leverage see their profits compound faster as they scale. The initial effort (building the product) pays off repeatedly without proportional cost increases.

  • Pareto principle connection: The 20% of effort you put into building scalable systems (automation, documentation, product foundation) generates 80% of long-term value. Companies with high operating leverage have figured out which 20% to focus on—the core systems that serve many customers without proportional cost increases.

This applies everywhere: - In career development: 20% of your skills generate 80% of your opportunities - In investing: 20% of decisions may drive 80% of returns - In technical writing: 20% of documentation gets 80% of user engagement - In relationships: 20% of quality time creates 80% of the bond

docs.title: How technical communication creates operating leverage
docs.text:
And here's where it gets interesting: good internal documentation is a perfect example of operating leverage.

You write it once, but it serves hundreds or thousands of employees. It reduces the need for repeated explanations, shortens onboarding time, and prevents mistakes through clear procedures. The initial investment compounds over time as more employees benefit without proportional cost increases.

But—and this is crucial—technical communication also has costs. You need resources to create and maintain documentation. Writers, technical editors, information architects. Tools and processes.

So the question becomes: how does investing in internal documentation contribute to revenue growing faster than expenses?

Here's how:

  1. Reduces indirect costs (operating leverage): Good internal docs mean senior engineers spend less time answering questions, new hires become productive faster, and teams waste less time searching for information. You can scale the organization without proportionally increasing "support overhead."

  2. Increases productivity (revenue enablement): Engineers who can quickly find answers ship features faster. Sales teams with clear product documentation close deals more efficiently. Better internal processes mean more output with the same headcount.

  3. Enables faster scaling (growth efficiency): When onboarding is well-documented, you can hire and ramp new employees faster. Clear runbooks mean teams can operate independently without constant escalation.

  4. Reduces costly errors (risk mitigation): Well-documented procedures prevent expensive mistakes. Clear architecture documentation prevents technical debt. Compliance documentation reduces regulatory risk.

The investment in internal technical communication should be evaluated like any business investment: does it help the organization produce more value (revenue) while keeping costs from growing proportionally?

If your internal docs team's cost grows more slowly than the time savings, productivity gains, and error prevention it creates, you've built operating leverage.

docs.title: How internal onboarding and learning experiences improve "the numbers"
docs.text:
Investors and execs care about profitability, efficiency, and growth. A lot of that comes from how well your organization scales—can you grow revenue without proportionally growing costs?

Good internal documentation and learning experiences directly impact this:

  • Faster time to productivity — New employees who get up to speed quickly cost less and contribute sooner. If good onboarding docs cut ramp time from 12 weeks to 8 weeks, that's 4 weeks of productive work you wouldn't have had. Across 100 new hires per year, that's 400 weeks of productive work recovered. That's operating efficiency.

  • Fewer errors and less rework — When people understand internal systems, processes, and standards, they make fewer mistakes. Fewer mistakes mean less waste, fewer production incidents, and less time spent fixing things. A clear runbook prevents a 2am incident that would have cost engineering hours and potential customer impact.

  • Reduced knowledge transfer burden — If internal docs and learning resources are good, senior employees don't need to spend hours explaining things to new people or answering the same questions repeatedly. That time is freed up for high-value work—building features, closing deals, improving operations.

When we improve internal onboarding and learning, we're not "just" making things nicer—we're improving the same efficiency and scalability levers that show up in the metrics investors care about.

docs.title: How tech comm can have greater impact on the business
docs.text:
If we only talk in terms of "pages written" or "courses released," we stay in our corner. If we learn how the business is measured—EBIT, EBITDA, operating leverage, efficiency, time-to-productivity, cost per employee—we can:

  1. Frame our work in business terms — "This onboarding documentation redesign will shorten time-to-productivity by 3 weeks per new hire, saving $X across Y annual hires" or "These runbooks reduced production incidents by Z%, preventing $X in incident response costs." That's the language that gets budget and buy-in.

  2. Prioritize what actually moves the needle — Not everything has to tie to a financial metric, but when we know which levers matter (onboarding speed, knowledge transfer efficiency, error reduction), we can align our documentation strategy to those levers. Focus on the 20% of internal documentation that solves 80% of employee problems.

  3. Show up in the right conversations — When we understand operating efficiency and capital allocation, we can sit at the table where "how do we scale from 200 to 500 employees" is discussed—and argue for documentation and learning infrastructure as part of that scaling strategy.

That's how internal tech comm moves from "nice to have" to "critical infrastructure for growth." Not by doing different work, but by naming and measuring the impact in the language the business already uses.

docs.title: Connecting it all back
docs.text:
The more I learn about what makes a business valuable from an investor's perspective, the more I realize how technical communication can directly impact the metrics that matter.

It's all compound interest: - The skills you build compound over your career - The investments you make compound over time - The scalable systems you create in business compound profits - The documentation you write compounds value for users

It's all about the Pareto principle: - Focus on the 20% of skills that generate 80% of career opportunities - Focus on the 20% of investments that drive 80% of returns - Focus on the 20% of business activities that create 80% of leverage - Focus on the 20% of documentation that answers 80% of user questions

And it's all about ROIC: - Get the best return on every dollar (or hour) you invest - Build systems that scale without proportional cost increases - Focus resources on high-leverage activities - Measure impact, not just output

Next up, I'll explore how the balance sheet helps us think about documentation as an asset, documentation debt as a liability, and how building "documentation equity" creates lasting business value.
